Louis,
Yoshitame looks like a correct reading, but sosho always leaves me w=
ondering if there aren't other kanji that could be "abbreviated" in the sam=
e way.  On the left side of the seppa dai there are faint kaisho style mei =
that might read Myochin.  If that's what it is I suppose that it could be t=
he plate maker.  

There is a Yoshitame listed in Wakayama and Haynes.  It'=
s Haynes #H12160.  Personal name Seiunsha [=E9=9D=92=E9=9B=B2=E8=88=8E], wo=
rked in Kanazawa in Kaga, ca. 1800, "made tsuba."

No mention of Myochin, b=
ut of course there were Myochin people making iron plate tsuba in Kaga at t=
hat time.

Jim




  Hi there,

  I have a tsuba that I am trying to do som=
e research on, it has an 
  elaborate grassscript type writing on it that I=
 have had 
  translated.   It turns out that it is a haiku peom written by =

  Baishitsu (1769-1852), and it means reads "Various impressions are 
  gi=
ven to me every time the scenery of the season where the plum tree 
  bloom=
s is seen". 

  There is also asignature which I am told is the engraver of=
 the 
  haiku poem, "Yoshitame".  Does anyone know who this person was or 
=
  what school he engraved for?

  Does anyone have information on this tsub=
a?

  Here is the link:

  http://www.japaneseswordcollector.com/tsuba.jpg
=

  Thanks in advance.

  Regards,

  Louis
